articles.title: Plane with ‘engine issues' circles Rottnest in flight drama
articles.summary: AirAsia flight bound for Bali was forced to circle over Rottnest Island after suffering engine issues shortly after leaving Perth during take off. The flight had been travelling from Perth to Bali when it had problems with the engine and had to circle.

articles.title: Nearly 20 years later, Biloxi-Ocean Springs Bridge Walking Path is still bringing the community together
articles.summary: Nearly 20 years after Hurricane Katrina destroyed the Biloxi-Ocean Springs Bridge, the walking path added during the rebuild is still making an impact. The walking path was created during the reconstruction work.    for people to walk on the path that was created.

articles.title: Spain's 16-day heatwave this month was ‘the most intense on record'

articles.summary: The 16-day heatwave Spain suffered this month was the most intense on record, according to the AEMET meteorological agency. The last record was set in July 2022. Forest fires are still burning across northern and western Spain.

articles.title: Spain's August heatwave was ‘most intense on record', weather agency says
articles.summary: Spain's August heatwave was the most intense on record, weather agency AEMET says. It is part of a trend toward more extreme summers due to climate change, according to the weather agency. AEMet says the heatwave lasted for 16 days.

articles.title: Spain's August heatwave was ‘most intense on record', weather agency says
articles.summary: Spain's August heatwave was the most intense on record, weather agency AEMET says. It is part of a trend toward more extreme summers due to climate change, according to the weather agency. AEMet says the heatwave lasted for 16 days.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'The UN's Krazy Kangaroo Klimate Kourt', By Paul Driessen
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: Vanuatu and other 'climate vulnerable' island nations claim they are threatened by rising seas and worsening typhoons caused by fossil fuel use. The United Nations General Assembly presented a resolution to the UN's International Court of Justice (ICJ or World Court). The ICJ ruled in July 2025 that greenhouse gas emissions are 'unequivocally caused by human activities' and are distributed throughout the atmosphere. The only places climate change is a 'crisis,' an 'existential problem of planetary proportions,' or a 'dire threat' to people and planet are in climate cult computer models, fearmongering and press releases.

articles.title: Why Ireland's mild temperatures won't protect it from the climate crisis
articles.summary: Ireland has a moderate climate with few temperature extremes. The recent severe storms have brought strong winds, more intense floods and a greater risk of blackouts and eroded coastlines. Climate change is a serious threat to wellbeing and, in the longer-term, survival of human life as we know it.

articles.title: World in deep waters of debt
articles.author: Dr Omer Javed
articles.summary: Economic policy is not learning from its mistakes, including over-board practice of austerity policies. This is happening even as the world is faced with polycrisis, including the existential threat of climate change crisis, and the related 'Pandemicene' phenomenon. It was only in 2022 that Pakistan saw one-third of its land come under water due to climate change-induced heavy rainfall, and floods. UNCTAD's report 'A World of Debt 2025' published in June adds to a list of important reports produced over the significant increase in global debt in recent years.

articles.title: Is Canada's $100B+ Climate Plan Based on Shaky Science?
articles.summary: Rising CO2 levels have been instrumental in promoting an ongoing planet-wide increase in vegetation cover. This is thanks to enhanced photosynthesis, water use efficiency and higher agricultural yields. There appears to be no serious impact on marine life. The authors conclude that while climate change is real and influenced by human emissions, its risks are often exaggerated.

articles.title: Everglades Fire Today: 5 Key Takeaways for Florida Homeowners
articles.author: The Realtor.com Team
articles.summary: Mile Marker 39 and Sawgrass fires in the Florida Everglades have burned over 1,850 acres by Tuesday afternoon. There is no immediate threat to structures or the public, but residents are facing challenges such as reduced visibility and poor air quality. The fires coincide with high heat advisories in Southeast Florida and the looming Hurricane Erin.

articles.title: From sea ice to ocean currents, Antarctica is now undergoing abrupt changes—and we'll all feel them
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Antarctica is undergoing abrupt and alarming changes. Sea ice is shrinking rapidly, the floating glaciers are melting faster and the ice sheets are carpeting the Southern Ocean. The ice-covered continent used to be seen as a remote, unchanging environment, but now it's changing rapidly.

articles.title: Queensland weather forecast sees sunny weather for last week of winter
articles.author: Aaron Kelly
articles.summary: Warm northerly winds will push temperatures up to the mid-to-high 30s in some parts of Queensland this week. On Tuesday, Birdsville is forecast to top 36 degrees Celsius and Mount Isa is heading for a maximum of 35 degrees Celsius. Brisbane and the Gold Coast will hit highs of 28 and 26 degrees Celsius by mid-week.

articles.title: Climate-hit cotton crop
articles.author: editorial
articles.summary: Pakistan's cotton output has declined by 17% over the past year. This season's cotton crops have been hit by extreme heatwaves and torrential monsoon rains. Policy failures have also played a role in the poor performance of the cotton industry. New taxes on ginning and inadequate subsidies for seeds slowed down ginning.

articles.title: BC Wildfire Service warns of increased fire danger during prolonged heat wave
articles.author: Canadian Press
articles.summary: There's a prolonged heat wave across much of B.C. which will increase fire danger in the coming days. Hot and dry weather conditions that began late last week are rapidly drying out forest fuels, warning of the increasing risk of new blazes being sparked. The southern Interior and inland coast will see high temperatures above 30 C.

articles.title: Rich Londoners find money can't buy ACs as temperatures soar
articles.author: Moneyweb
articles.summary: Temperatures in some parts of the London Underground have exceeded levels deemed fit for cattle. Climate change is transforming the experience of living in Britain's capital, according to the experts.      Â   y   in the UK.

articles.title: Heat Stress at Work: WHO & WMO Guidance ☀️
articles.author: Dr. Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: WHO and WMO have released a report on climate change and workplace heat stress. According to the report, 2.4 billion people are exposed to excessive heat at work every year, resulting in over 22.85 million occupational injuries annually. The report recommends developing occupational heat-health policies tailored to specific industries, regions, and worker vulnerabilities. New technologies, such as cooling vests and wearable sensors, can play a vital role in safeguarding worker health.

articles.title: BC Wildfire Service warns of increased fire danger during prolonged heat wave
articles.author: Canadian Press
articles.summary: BC Wildfire Service warns of increased fire danger during prolonged heat wave. The southern Interior and inland coast will see high temperatures above 30 C, and near 30 C in the central and northern parts of B.C. The wildfire service says so-called crossover conditions where temperatures exceed relative humidity increase the risk of new fires.

articles.title: The Irish Times view on Europe's hot summer: a clear weather warning
articles.summary: July 2025 was the 12th warmest month in 126 years of Irish records. Five of the top ten warmest Julys have occurred since 2006. Southern Europe is experiencing one of its worst wildfire seasons in 20 years. This year, wildfires have destroyed 382,000 hectares in Spain.

articles.title: Australia's security policy is overly expensive, severely flawed
articles.author: Newcastle Herald
articles.summary: Explore Australia's need for a strategic shift in defence policy, moving away from AUKUS dependencies and away from its dependency on the US market.       in Australia's Defence Policy Review, published by Australian National Security Council, is available online.

articles.title: Antarctica nears tipping point amid accelerating climate shifts
articles.summary: Antarctica is showing worrying signs of rapid change across its ice, ocean and ecosystems. Abrupt and irreversible changes in the continent driven by climate change could lift global oceans by metres and lead to 'catastrophic consequences for generations', scientists warned last Wednesday.

articles.title: Calgary, most of Alberta expected to see high temperatures over the week
articles.author: Postmedia Calgary
articles.summary: Calgary, along with most of Alberta, is forecasted to see high temperatures over the course of the coming week. Environment Canada has issued a special weather statement for most of the province warning for a 'long duration heat event' with temperatures up to 33 C in northern Alberta. Edmonton has activated its extreme heat response as the city is under a heat warning.

articles.title: Climate Change's Mental Health Effects on Vulnerable Groups
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Asim and Ilyas have published a study in Discov Psychol about the psychological consequences of climate change on at-risk populations. They argue that climate change's effects are personal and experienced on an individual level. They call for the development of therapeutic models specifically designed to support those grappling with climate-related stress.

articles.title: Pacific nations back Australia's Bid to Host COP31
articles.summary: The Pacific Islands Forum supports Australia's bid to host the 31st UN Climate Change Conference of the Parties (COP31) in 2026. The ministers pledged to champion the needs of all countries most affected by climate change.

articles.title: Blackberries ripen ‘earliest in two decades' after sweltering summer
articles.author: Albert Tait
articles.summary: This summer has been one of the warmest in the UK since records began in 1884. England entered its fourth heatwave earlier this month and five areas are in drought. The earliest ripe blackberries were spotted in London on June 22, almost two weeks earlier than the first recorded berries in 2024.

articles.title: Spain heatwave was 'most intense on record'
articles.author: AFP AFP
articles.summary: A 16-day heatwave Spain suffered this month was "the most intense on record", the national meteorological agency said on Sunday. The average temperature was 4.6C higher than previous events. There are forest fires still burning across northern and western Spain.

articles.title: 109-year-old heat record broken in Victoria Saturday
articles.author: Lisa Steacy
articles.summary: All five weather stations in Victoria-area registered a high of 31.1 C on Saturday, beating the previous record of 30.0 C set in 1916. Comox and Courtenay on Vancouver Island also had high of 30C, while Lytton had 38.6 C. On the Lower Mainland, Abbotsford hit 34.2 C, breaking a 91-year-old record. Pitt Meadows saw high of 33 C. Heat warnings were lifted for many regions Sunday, only remaining for the province's north coast.

articles.title: UK weather: Has the British summer changed beyond recognition?
articles.author: Ben Rich
articles.summary: This summer has been very warm in the UK. Eight of the last 10 summers have seen temperatures above the long-term average. The number of days with temperatures above 30C has more than trebled in the most recent decade compared with the 1961-1990 average. In the future, summers will become hotter and drier, with more frequent droughts and wildfires.

articles.title: Tree plantation will save shortage of water across Sindh, Campaign helds in various cities.
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: Cities in Sindh are facing water shortages, with groundwater levels rapidly declining. Karachi and Larkana are also facing environmental and water issues due to climate change. Urdu Point and Pakistan Point News will broadcast on 24th August 2025.

articles.title: Is It Still Time to Reverse the Climate Crisis?
articles.summary: It is still possible to limit global warming to 1.5oC, but opportunity windows are closing, according to the Sixth IPCC Assessment Report (Intergovernmental Panel on Mudan) Science points out that, technically, it's still possible, but opportunities are closing rapidly.

articles.title: Victoria area in B.C. breaks nearly 100-year-old temperature record amid hot spell

articles.summary: A heat warning is in effect for inland regions of the North Coast of B.C. until mid-week. There is no rain in the forecast for most of the province this week. A ridge of high pressure is bringing elevated temperatures to the region this weekend and into early next week.

articles.author: newsdesk@devonlive.com
articles.summary: Exminster, Barnstaple and several coastal towns along Devon's north and south coasts could be partially submerged by 2050, according to a map developed by Climate Central. East England coastline from Hull to Norfolk is potentially the most severely impacted region. The report by MPs found that melting ice caps could put up to 1.5 million properties at an increased risk of flooding by 2080 due to rising seas caused by melting Arctic ice.

articles.title: Dealing with flooding requires collective effort
articles.summary: Floods and landslides in May 2024 affected 39,185 people (about 8,011 households) across 14 districts in Uganda. Flooding events in August and September 2024 affected nearly 44,400 people, displacing approximately 25,400, and causing severe damage to homes, schools, water points, and health facilities. Climate scientists warn that extreme rainfall events in East Africa will become more frequent and intense due to global warming. Natural disasters cost Uganda 3-5% of GDP annually.

articles.title: Flood situation turns grim in Sultanpur Lodhi's Mand region
articles.author: Ashok Kaura

articles.summary: PM Pham Minh Chinh arrived at the Home Front Command Center on the evening of August 24 to oversee and command the response efforts to Typhoon Kajiki. The disaster risk level has been raised to Level 4, classified as "very high" for coastal areas from Thanh Hoa to Quang Tri and inland areas in Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces during the storm's landfall. The storm is expected to make landfall in the late afternoon or evening on August 25.

articles.title: Pro-Palestine protesters fill streets across Australia after Gaza famine declaration
articles.summary: Sunday's marches are expected to be the largest pro-Palestine demonstrations in Australia's history. The action comes days after the UN confirmed famine in parts of the Gaza Strip for the first time. Israel is preparing for a military takeover of Gaza City.

articles.author: Al Jazeera
articles.summary: Thousands of Australians rallied across the country, demanding an end to genocide in Gaza and sanctions against Israel for its atrocities in the Palestinian enclave. articles.title: Spain's Hottest Heatwave on Record Fuels Devastating Wildfires
articles.author: Kriti Dhingra
articles.summary: Spain has experienced the country's most intense heatwave on record. The 16-day extreme weather event lasted between August 3 and 18. The previous record was set in July 2022. Wildfires have ravaged large swathes of the country, especially in Castile and Leon, Extremadura, and Galicia.

articles.title: Spain Heatwave: Record-Breaking Intensity & Impacts
articles.summary: There were over 1,100 deaths during Spain's recent heatwave. It was the most intense on record, averaging 4.6°C higher than historical norms. Since 1975, AEMET has documented 77 heatwaves in Spain, but a concerning trend is emerging: six have exceeded the 4°C threshold, and five of those have occurred since 2019. Heatwaves are becoming more frequent, more intense, and longer-lasting across the globe, driven by rising greenhouse gas emissions. The future isn't predetermined, but it demands immediate and decisive action.

articles.title: Sorry But Here's What The World's Most Famous Attractions Will Look Like In 2050
articles.author: Kate Nicholson
articles.summary: DiscoverCars.com has compiled a set of visuals showing how popular tourist destinations around the world could be hit by the climate crisis in just a matter of years. The visuals examine how natural disasters, flooding, acid rain, land erosion and rising sea levels may alter some of the world's most beloved landscapes by 2050. Hawaii, for instance, is more likely to experience increased volcanic activity and earthquakes, while Egypt's Greater Cairo area could have more acid rain which may erode the Pyramids of Giza. Rising sea levels could submerge the majority of London docks and suburbs near the Thames, meaning the London Eye, Parliament and London Bridge might all be underwater.

articles.title: ‘LIFE IN A BUBBLE'
articles.summary: Climate advocates hold a program they dubbed 'Life in a Bubble' to show the disparity between the rich and poor when it comes to exposure to air pollution on Sunday, August 24, 2025 in Marikina City. The program is called Life in a bubble.

articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Air turbulence can be unnerving for many flyers, especially during long flights. The seatbelt sign pings on, trays rattle, drinks slosh in their glasses, and trays and glasses get disturbed by turbulence. It's a world warming under the effects of turbulence.

articles.title: Bangladesh issues signal No. 3 for ports as fresh low brews in Bay
articles.author: Staff Correspondent
articles.summary: Bangladesh Meteorological Department has warned of a fresh low-pressure system forming in the Bay of Bengal. Seaports have been advised to hoist local cautionary signal No. 3. The existing low over Gangetic West Bengal has already weakened and merged with the monsoon trough, but another one could develop by Monday night or Tuesday. The forecast suggests light to moderate rain or thundershowers with gusty winds in many parts of Rangpur, Rajshahi, Mymensingh, Dhaka, Khulna, Barishal, Chattogram and Sylhet divisions.

articles.title: Climate change and prey could be driving great white sharks north

articles.title: Wildfire disasters are increasingly in the news, yet less land is burning globally – here's why (Opinion)
articles.author: Mojtaba Sadegh
articles.summary: An estimated 440 million people were exposed to a wildfire encroaching on their home between 2002 and 2021. The total area burned has declined by 26% in Africa. Agricultural activities in Africa are fragmenting wildland areas that are prone to burning. The number of days conducive to extreme fire behavior and new fire ignitions has increased by more than 50% over the past 50 years.

articles.title: Lough Neagh: Environmental crisis at UK's largest freshwater lake has 'become a political problem'
articles.author: Rebecca Black
articles.summary: Blue-green algae has returned to Lough Neagh for the third summer in a row this week. This summer the condition of the lough caused the eel-fishing season to be cut short and two north coast beaches to close for bathing at the weekend. Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs Minister Andrew Muir is determined to turn the situation around. Gerry Darby is frustrated with a lack of action and claims it's a political problem.

articles.title: Florida Senate Bill 180 threatens and local planning statewide
articles.summary: Orange County's Vision 2050 is in legal limbo because of a new state law passed just months ago. The law, Senate Bill 180, was sold as a post-hurricane 'emergency measure' to help communities rebuild faster, but it strips away local control. It applies retroactively to August 1, 2024 and runs until October 1, 2027. Landowners behind the proposed Sustanee mega-development in Orange County have already filed suit against the county, citing SB 180. 1000 Friends of Florida commissioned a legal analysis by noted Florida land-use attorney Richard Grosso. They are urging the Florida Legislature to repeal the damaging parts of SB 180 in 2026 and restore local

More than 40 protests took place across the country, according to Palestine Action Group.

articles.summary: The city has had 14 days above 32 C so far this year, double the annual average. Experts say Toronto needs to prepare for that to be par for the course for the next 25 years. The city has not had that many above 32C days in 25 years, according to experts.

articles.title: The truth about whether you burn more calories in the heat

articles.summary: According to Nuffield Health expert Keiren Douglas, working out in high temperatures does not burn more calories than in low temperatures. articles.summary: This summer has been one of the hottest on record in Toronto, with six heat waves recorded already. It's almost like a dress rehearsal of what summers are going to be like in 2050, he says.

articles.author: your NEWS Media Newsroom
articles.summary: Research indicates coral reefs expanded most rapidly during past warm periods when sea levels were higher. When sea surface temperatures were 1-2°C warmer than today and sea levels about 1 meter higher, reef accretion reached 15 millimeters per year, the fastest rates recorded in 8,500 years.

Under its influence, gusty or squally weather may affect the maritime ports, the North Bay and adjoining coastal areas of Bangladesh. articles.title: Rising visitor numbers are leaving a harmful human footprint on Antarctica's ecosystems

articles.summary: Antarctic tourism and research bases are polluting the southern continent. The average tourist trip generates 5.44 tonnes of CO2 emissions per passenger. Scientists say visitors disturb wildlife, trample fragile flora and increase the risk of introducing invasive species and diseases. The Antarctic Treaty bans the use of pollutants like heavy fuel oil.

articles.title: Surging tourism is polluting Antarctica, scientists warn
articles.author: Craig Saueurs
articles.summary: Antarctic tourism has boomed. In the 2024-25 season, 118,491 tourists visited the region. Concentrations of toxic metals such as nickel, copper and lead are 10 times higher than they were in the 1990s. The average tourist trip generates 5.44 tonnes of CO2 emissions per passenger.

articles.title: Forrest Place full as Perth crowds join national pro-Palestine rally
articles.author: Cameron Myles
articles.summary: Forrest Place in the heart of Perth's CBD was full on Sunday as a big crowd joined national pro-Palestine marches. The march was one of several organised in major cities and towns across Australia. It follows the march of about 100,000 people across the Sydney Harbour Bridge earlier this month.

articles.title: 'Enough is enough': Palestine support swells
articles.author: Samantha Lock
articles.summary: Hundreds of thousands of people are marching across Australia in support for Palestinians. They are marching in support of the dying and starving Palestinians.   in dozens of Australian cities and towns. They want to protest against Israel's treatment of the Palestinians and for their rights.

articles.title: Torrential Downpour Brings Havoc to Jharkhand: Alert Issued
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Jharkhand remains in the grip of relentless rain. The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) has sounded alerts in several districts until Tuesday morning. Five casualties have been reported, while the farming community suffers substantial crop and livestock losses. The IMD anticipates a continuation of this pattern as a low-pressure area forms over the Bay of Bengal by Monday.

articles.title: Global warming curbing workers' productivity: WHO
articles.author: Bloomberg
articles.summary: A warming planet is affecting workers' health and productivity, according to a joint study by the World Health Organization and the World Meteorological Organization. Last year was the hottest on record, and daytime temperatures of 40C and even 50C are becoming more common. Workers' productivity drops by 2% to 3% for every degree above 20C. Almost half of the global population suffers from the adverse consequences of global warming.

articles.title: UN agencies warn extreme heat poses growing threat to workers' health
articles.author: NEWS WIRE
articles.summary: WHO and WMO have released a joint report on climate change and workplace heat stress. The report details how extreme heat is reshaping the world of work. 2024 was the hottest year on record, at 1.55 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial temperatures. Worker productivity drops by 2 to 3 per cent for every degree above 20°C.

articles.title: Expert raises concerns over growing trend making wildfires worse: 'This is ridiculous'
articles.summary: Wildfires have become a major problem on the West Coast. Earth's rising temperature is at the forefront of the conversation. Dry conditions from longer and more intense droughts allow the fires to spread faster without rainfall to slow them down. Human intervention from the lumber is also a factor.

articles.title: Rallies under way as Palestine support swells
articles.author: William Ton
articles.summary: Hundreds of thousands of people have gathered in Australian cities and towns to march in support of the Palestinian cause. The march comes after famine was declared in Gaza for the first time and in response to the situation in the Gaza Strip.   in Australia, there is a groundswell of support for Palestine.

articles.title: AP on alert as new low pressure likely in Bay of Bengal in two days
articles.author: Pavan Bandari
articles.summary: Andhra Pradesh has been placed on high alert as a low pressure system threatens the region. A new low pressure area is expected to form in the northwestern Bay of Bengal and along the Odisha-West Bengal coasts by 25 August. The system is likely to move towards Jharkhand within the next 24 hours. Southwesterly and westerly winds are affecting the state, leading to predicted rainfall over the next three days.

articles.title: Kutubdia extremely needs a sustainable embankment
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: There are 40 kilometres of embankments in Kutubdia, of which 6.5 kilometer stretches are damaged. The existing embankment of the Water Development Board built on the western side of Tablerchar, Kaharpara, Shaitpara and Haidarpara is constantly caving in due to strong tidal waves in the sea. At least 30 houses have been destroyed and hundreds of acres of cropland and salt fields submerged in brackish water.

articles.title: Chalmers has ‘no plans' to alter tax-free retiree super
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Hundreds of thousands of Australians are expected to march in support for the Palestinian cause.      Â   in a nationwide groundswell of support for Palestine. Â "Hundreds of millions of Australians will march for Palestine on March 8th.

articles.title: LPA & Habagat: Rain Forecasts for VisMin & Luzon ☔️
articles.summary: Philippines is bracing itself for an intensifying cyclone season due to climate change. PAGASA is working to improve its early warning systems and develop localized warning systems tailored to the specific risks faced by different communities. The economic consequences of increasingly frequent and intense cyclones extend far beyond immediate damage to infrastructure.

articles.title: FCOSS urges stronger climate collaboration
articles.summary: The Fiji Council of Social Services is calling for stronger collaboration between the government, civil society and the private sector to combat the growing effects of climate change. Climate change is already displacing families and threatening food and water security. The Fiji Climate Change Act provides an important legal framework for this work.

articles.title: British Airways drama as 20 people kicked off plane after it became too heavy
articles.author: The Mirror
articles.summary: The extreme conditions that caused the unexpected deplaning are only likely to get more common as the impact of climate change is felt, according to an aviation expert, because of the warming climate. The expert warned that the extreme conditions caused by climate change are likely to become more common.

articles.title: Light pollution tricking urban birds into staying awake longer each day
articles.author: Hannah Devlin
articles.summary: Light pollution is causing birds to sing for longer each day, prolonging their vocalisations on average by 50 minutes. American robin, Northern mocking bird and European goldfinch extended their day by more than average. Small-eyed species such as sparrows didn't respond as well to artificial light.

articles.title: Australia PM Albanese slams Netanyahu as ‘in denial about the consequences' of Gaza war
articles.author: News24
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese says that Israel's leader Benjamin Netanyahu is in denial about the suffering inflicted on Gaza. The international community is now saying: 'Enough is enough' and the world is calling for an end to the Israeli occupation of Gaza, he adds.

articles.title: From sea ice to ocean currents, Antarctica is now undergoing abrupt changes – and we'll ...
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: Nerilie Abram, Ariaan Purich, Felicity McCormack, Jan Strugnell, James Cook University, and Matthew England, UNSW Sydney are talking about Antarctica and the changing environment on the ice-covered continent. They are from the Australian National University, Monash University, JCU and UNSW.

articles.title: Hundreds of thousands expected at pro-Palestine protests across Australia after Gaza famine declaration
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: Hundreds of thousands of Australians are expected to march in support for the Palestinian cause on Sunday. It's days after famine was declared in Gaza for the first time. Organisers expect it to be the largest pro-Palestine demonstrations in Australia's history. Every major Palestine march will be bigger than before.

articles.title: Global warming curbing workers' productivity: WHO
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: A warming planet is affecting workers' health and productivity, according to a joint study by the World Health and World Health Organization. Workers face a growing risk of heatstroke, dehydration, kidney dysfunction and other effects due to the increasing frequency and intensity of heat waves.

articles.title: 2025, the year of the mosquito
articles.author: Dr. Sylvester Ikhisemojie
articles.summary: This year was actually named the year of the snake by the Chinese. This year may well have been named the Year of the Mosquito. The concern surrounding mosquitoes is not merely about itchy bites but about their accelerating capacity to transmit deadly pathogens to human populations. The warming climate serves as the primary engine driving the global expansion of mosquito-borne diseases. Rapid urbanisation across tropical and subtropical regions has created ideal conditions for mosquito proliferation.

articles.title: NorthWestern ignores the true costs of fossil fuels
articles.summary: Brian Bird, CEO of NorthWestern Energy, earns $4.8 million per year. Climate change is making Montana's weather more extreme and hotter. Last year 20% of the increase in global energy demand was due to extreme weather. In the U.S. 489,000 people die yearly from heat, and 37% of these deaths are attributed to human-caused climate change. The company's loyalty to fossil fuels is causing climate change, and we're stuck with the consequences.

articles.title: Feature: Communities in Rwanda's climate-vulnerable areas lead the fight against climate change
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Nyabihu and Ngororero districts in Rwanda's Western Province are pilot sites for a pioneering community-led climate adaptation project. In May 2023, floods and landslides across Western Province killed more than 100 people and destroyed thousands of homes, schools, and key infrastructure. The initiative, funded by the Global Center on Adaptation, ensures that projects are climate-resilient.

articles.title: Pro-Palestine demonstrations held across Australian cities
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Pro-Palestinian demonstrations were held across Australia on Sunday. Organizers claim crowd numbers to be in the tens of thousands. The national rallies follow a recent demonstration in Sydney that shut down the Harbor Bridge. Bruce McPhate, who participated in the demonstration in Melbourne, said what drove him to participate was the impact of the Gaza war on children.

articles.title: Spain's recent heat wave recorded as ‘most intense'
articles.author: Ilayda Cakirtekin
articles.summary: The recent heat wave in Spain was the most intense since records began. The 16-day period between August 3 and 18 was 4.6 degrees Celsius above the seasonal average. The agency Aemet attributed the increase in the number of heat waves to climate change. Wildfires have scorched over 407,000 hectares (1 million acres) across Spain since early August.

articles.title: Feature: Communities in Rwanda's climate-vulnerable areas lead the fight against climate change
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: Nyabihu and Ngororero districts in Rwanda's Western Province have been chosen as pilot sites for a pioneering community-led climate adaptation. Residents have been trained on climate change adaptation and sensitized on its causes and how to mitigate and prevent its adverse effects.

articles.title: UK weather: Has the British summer changed beyond recognition?
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: climate change means UK summers are getting hotter.      Â   for the next few decades.  for this reason, the number of summers in the UK is getting hotter, according to the UK Met Office. For more information, visit: www.ukmetoffice.org.uk.

articles.title: British Airways chaos as 20 people kicked off plane after it became too heavy
articles.author: Daily Record
articles.summary: The extreme conditions that caused the unexpected deplaning are only likely to get more common as the impact of climate change is felt, according to an aviation expert. The weather conditions caused the deplaning were caused by extreme weather conditions. The cause was caused by climate change.

articles.title: Australia tops new list of most expensive passports in the world - but here's the ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: The Australian passport is the most expensive in the world for the second year in a row. A ten-year Australian passport costs $412, which works out to an average fee of $41.20 per year. This is well ahead of the U.S. passport.

articles.title: Is summer getting longer where you live? See how temperatures changed.
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: The hottest stretch of the year is expanding beyond any calendar definition of summer. See what regions are experiencing the biggest change here.    .      "Hottest stretch of summer" includes the hottest month in the last few years, and the hottest place on earth.

articles.title: Europe's wildfires burned land larger than Cyprus this summer
articles.author: Philenews
articles.summary: Europe is experiencing its worst wildfire season on record as the continent warms faster than any other region in the world. Europe is heating by 0.53°C per decade, more than in any other place in the globe except the Americas. The continent was previously spared from extreme weather events such as monsoons or hurricanes.

articles.title: Climate models reveal how human activity may be locking the American Southwest into permanent drought
articles.author: Space
articles.summary: Human activity may be driving drought more intensely and directly than previously understood, according to a new wave of climate research. The research is sounding a stark warning about the impact of human activity on climate change.    iReport.com: What do you think? Share your thoughts.

articles.title: Huge pro-Palestine crowd marches in Melbourne as part of national rally
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Victorian activists joined a nationwide pro-Palestine demonstration that kicked off in cities across Australia on Sunday. The protest is in response to rising starvation in Gaza, which has been declared a state of emergency in recent days.      .

articles.title: Huge rise in rescues as global warming makes mountains seem more inviting
articles.author: Sunday Post
articles.summary: Global warming is significantly increasing the risk of heatwaves.       in the U.S. and in the world at large scale. Global warming is also increasing the chances of droughts.  "It's not just a matter of getting warmer, it's about getting hotter"

articles.title: Hot weather breaks 38-year-old temperature record in West Vancouver
articles.author: North Shore News
articles.summary: It was 30.1 C in West Vancouver yesterday. The previous record for Saturday, August 23 was 29.0 C in 1987. Abbotsford, Pittsburg and Vancouver also had record-breaking temperatures yesterday. It was hot on the North Shore yesterday.

articles.title: Maritime ports across Bangladesh asked to hoist local cautionary signal No 3
articles.author: United News
articles.summary: Maritime ports of Chattogram, Cox's Bazar, Mongla and Payra have been advised to hoist local cautionary signal No 3 due to deep convection over the North Bay due to active monsoon. Under its influence, gusty or squally weather may affect the maritime ports and adjoining coastal areas of Bangladesh.
